ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: First-principles investigations on thermodynamic properties of the ordered and disordered Si0.5Ge0.5 alloys

Affiliation.OrgDivision: State Key Laboratory of Metastable Materials Science and Technology

Affiliation.OrgName: Hebei Normal University of Science and Technology

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The structure, formation energy, and thermodynamic properties of Si0.5Ge0.5 alloys are investigated through first-principles method. The ordered and disordered structures of Si0.5Ge0.5 compounds are considered. Our results show that thermodynamic instabilities of Si0.5Ge0.5 alloys at 0 K can be judged from the calculated formation energy. However, the alloy might be prepared at specified environment owing to the entropy effects considered. Moreover, the temperature dependence of the heat capacity, Debye temperature and thermal expansion coefficient of ordered and disordered structures are discussed.

$\mathrm{Si}_{x}\mathrm{Ge}_{1- x}$ alloys [1–6]. The ordered structure rhombohedra (RH) phases are observed in the GeSi/Si strained superlattices system at 550 °C [7]. However, an irreversible transition from the ordered structure to disordered structure occurs after annealing over 650 °C [8]. Whiteaker et al. found that the temperature for ordered-disordered transition phase to happen needs to be up to 700 °C [9]. Tsang et al. found that the needed temperature is 800 °C [10]. From the above it can be seen that the thermodynamic property is very complicated of

1 − x

In this work, to obtain more information about the thermodynamic parameters and develop application potential of semiconductor SiGe alloy at elevated temperature, we investigate the thermodynamic properties of ordered and disordered phase Si0.5Ge0.5 alloy, through first-principles calculations based on the density functional theory. Here, zinc-blende (ZB) and rhombohedra (RH) are considered as the ordered phases of Si0.5Ge0.5 alloy. To simulate disordered Si0.5Ge0.5 alloy, the special quasi-random structure (SQS) approach is used. In the SQS approach, random structures are designed to mimic the most relevant, near-neighbor pair and multisite correlation functions of the random substitutional alloys [11–13]. In our calculations, SQSs with 32 atoms/cell are employed to compute properties at composition of 0.50.

Section1.Heading: Calculation methods
Section1.Para:
First-principles calculations are performed with the CASTEP code [14] based on the density-function theory. Ultrasoft pseudopotentials are employed to describe the electron–ion interactions. The electronic exchange correlation potential is described by the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) parameterized by Perder, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) [15]. In the structure calculation, a plane-wave basis set with energy cut-off of 400 eV is used. Pseudo atomic calculations are performed for Si

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: The structural and thermodynamic properties of the Si0.5Ge0.5 alloy are investigated through first-principles calculations based on the density functional theory. The ordered and disordered structures of Si0.5Ge0.5 alloy are considered. Our results for the equilibrium lattice parameter and bulk modulus are consistent with the previous calculated and experimental results. The formation energy calculated shows that the SiGe alloy is unstable at 0 K; however, the alloy might exist at specified temperature scale. Through the quasi-harmonic Debye model, the temperature dependence of bulk modulus, heat capacity, Debye temperature and volume thermal expansion coefficient are predicted successfully.
